Name: Treble Treasure
Description:
There are two sets of composer discs numbered from 1 to 36. Place numbers 1 through 18 on the board in random order. Use the set of cards numbered 1 through 18 with the composers' names on them. Place these composer cards, which correspond to the discs on the board, in a pile with the names of the composers showing. Each player takes his turn identifying the composer whose name is on the top card by calling out the number which appears on the disc with the picture of the composer whose name is on the card.

And eduactional memory game.

Name: Gangsters et compagnie
Description:
Play with gangsters and cops using cards.
On one hand, there are 4 gangs with a godfather leading them. On the other side, 15 cops are trying to avoid the gangsters to rob a bank.

Gangster et Compagnie is played in two teams. The dealer, the player with the bank and the player with the bomb are one team. All the others are the second team.
These teams play tricks. In a trick where the first card is a Gang or Police, other players can follow or play whatever (if they can't follow). In a trick where the first card is a Bank or Bomb, nobody can play a card. The round ends a soon a player played his last card.
The team with most points in the tricks, win the round.

Name: Meine Goldene Wetterau
Description:
Take an exiting journey across the Wetterau, a broad fertile landscape in the western German state of Hessen!

In Meine Goldene Wetterau, players guide a single hiker along the paths through the cities and communities of the Wetterau, trying to direct the hiker to locations that match the cards they hold in hand. Each player has a hand of four cards, with the remaining cards being placed next to the game board as a deck. On a turn, a player takes one or both of these actions in this order:


    Move the hiker along the path 1-3 locations in a direction of their choice.
    Play location cards from their hand that match where the hiker is located or where it started the turn.


At the end of their turn, a player refills their hand to four cards. Play continues until the deck runs out and one player has no cards left in hand. Whoever has played the most location cards wins!

Name: Combat Leader: Poland 1939
Description:
From the publisher's webpage:

Combat Leader: Poland 1939 is the newest release in the Combat Leader game series, covering the Polish campaign on September, 1939, with German and Polish troops.

The game comes with two maps (#9 and #10, rural and suburban terrain), two counter sheets (J & K, which must be cut apart), two identical Reference Cards, and a 24-page rules booklet.  The rules contain all the standard, advanced, and optional rules for the system, along with five scenarios.  This game sees the entry of the Poles into the system, and special rules cover the use of the 18-man Polish squad, with their characteristic weaponry (Kb wz.98a rifles, Browning wz. 1928 BAR LMG, etc.) and organization. The German SS also are introduced into the system (a full SS squad is included), with special rules governing their use on the battlefield. Overall, three German squads, two Polish squads--plus plenty of extra men to create different formations--are included.

The core rules have been expanded to include several options originally appearing in the Combat Leader: Expansion Module.  These rules are now  considered standard, and there is no need to buy that module.

Combat Leader: Poland is a complete, stand alone game. The core rules of the game system remain the same, plus additional optional rules have been included. So, Combat Leader: Poland 1939 provides you with not only a new nationality and the SS, but the most up-to-date edition of the series.  It is compatible with all other Combat Leader games.

Name: Dice Derbi
Description: Dice Derbi is a dexterity dice tossing game where players form teams, casting lures (dice) onto one of two game boards, trying to hit the honey hole and catch the largest fish.  Based on fishing yet easily played by all ages.

Name: Yesterdays: 60's and 70's Edition
Description: The musical cassette game. Correctly answer questions on the provided cassettes in a race to reach the finish space first. Questions may be musical clues, spoken lyrics, multiple choice, complete the lyric, or identify the year.

Name: Wraith
Description:
Description from the publisher:

In Wraith, you must recruit champions and use your magic to reach into cross over to The Other Side and bring powerful spirits back to the land of the living. Once summoned, your wraiths may fight along side you or merge with you and your champions to give you supernatural abilities, armor, and more! Face off against your friends with competitive battles or team up to stop the encroaching darkness with both campaign and defense co-op play.

Wraith is a fast-paced deck-building game for 1-4 players that focuses on recruiting and building up champions to defeat your opponents. The game features three modes of game play: competitive versus, co-op campaign, and defensive co-op. The campaign and defense variations can also be played solo.

Name: Judgmental
Description:
Description from the publisher:

Judgmental is a party game in which famous figures do battle and players decide who wins. Each player secretly chooses a contender card from their hand, and those cards are dealt into a bracket. Match-ups are decided by unique and silly contests, and a vote by all players determines the victor. You win if your chosen contender gets all the way to the finals and wins the vote.

Name: Palaeo Diet: Eat or be Eaten
Description:
Palaeo Diet: Eat or be Eaten  is a stand-alone set of gaming rules for recreating prehistoric animal hunts on your table top. The game models a time when humans were not yet in control of the world around them, when the landscape could just as easily give succour to a struggling tribe, as it could cripple a thriving people.

Designed with solo and multiplayer games in mind, players take on the role of the hunting party while an integral response mechanism means that beasts react in different ways in different situations.
Families: Series: Song of Blades and Heroes

Name: El Libertador
Description:
A board game for 2-4+ players themed on the Latin American revolutions 1809 - 1826.

The board is a circular track of 41 spaces.  Eight countries are represented on the track by a series of consecutive spaces of length 3, 4 or 5. Countries are separated from each other on the track by a revolution space

Players share a common deck comprising cards of two main types: Liberation cards and Royalist cards. There are 5 types of Liberation Cards: Simon Bolivar, Leader, Troops, Battle, and Ideals. All cards have a force value between 1 and 8.

Players start with two cards drawn from the deck and a set of counters and markers.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 5 Phases:

Draw Phase

     Draw 1 Card and place it in your hand. 


Move Phase

     Roll 1 die and move forward that many spaces OR discard a card from your hand and move forward a number of spaces equal to its force value. 
     If you land on a Revolution space you may do one of three actions: 
         Roll the die and move again
         Move to any other Revolution space on the board
         Draw 1 card and place it in your hand
         Play a counter onto any country space you have liberated
    


Action Phase

      If you land on a Country space that has no card on it, you may (but do not have to) play a Liberation card to that space. Tuck it partially under the board directly next to the space. Place 1 of your counters on the space if you placed a card there. If you have a card under a space you are said to have liberated it. 
     If you land on a Country space that you have already liberated (You have a card and one or more counters there already) you may do one of the following: 
         Place an additional counter on the Space
         Exchange the tucked card with one from your hand  
         Draw 1 card and discard 1 card (It may be the same card) 
    
     If you land on a Country space liberated by another player, you can either do nothing or play 1 or more Royalist cards with a combined force value equal to or greater than the number of counters your opponent has on the space. If you do so, discard all the counters on the space and the card tucked under it. Remove the Royalist cards from the game. 
     If you land on a Country space that is Independent skip over it and go to the next space and resume your move. 


Independence Phase

     If you played a Liberation card under a Country space this turn and all the other spaces for that country have already been liberated (by you or others) the Country is now said to have gained its Independence. Immediately score Victory Tokens (VT) for the country. 
         You gain 2 Victory Tokens for playing the final card to make the country go Independent. 
         The player with the highest combined total of counters and card force values gets 5 VT. 
         The player with the second highest total of counters and card force values gets 3 VT. 
         All other players with at least 1 card and counter in the country get 1 VT each. 
    


End Phase

     Max hand size is 5 cards. Discard excess cards. 


The game ends when all countries have been liberated. The player with the most VT at the end of the game wins.

Name: Doctor Who Episodes
Description:
A rummy style card game for 2-4+ players with a Dr Who theme focused on Doctors 9-11.

Players share a common deck comprising 15 cards in each of 6 suits: Doctors, Companions, Gadgets, Foes, Plots and Specials. Cards have a force point value ranging from 1 to 15.

Players are dealt 7 cards each and then take turns with each turn comprising 4 phases:

Draw Phase

     Draw 2 cards from the top of the deck and put them in your hand. 


Action Phase

     You may play (discard) one card from your hand to activate its special ability. 
         Discard a Doctor card to look at the next 7 cards in the deck. 
         Discard a Companion card to draw 2 cards. 
         Discard a Foe card to steal 1 random card from an opponent’s hand. 
         Discard a Plot card to look at an opponent’s hand.  
         Discard a Gadget card to draw 3 cards, keep 1 and discard the other 2. 
         Discard a Special card to cause target opponent to discard 1 random card. 
    


Episode Phase

     If possible you may play (discard) one episode from your hand. An episode consists of one card of each of the 6 card types. The total value of the FP for the Doctor, Companion, and Gadget cards must exceed the total FP value of the Foe, Plot, and Special cards (The Threat). 
     Gain Victory Points equal to the value of the Threat. 
     After completing an episode draw 4 cards from the deck. 


End Phase

     Max hand size is 7 cards. Discard excess cards. 


The first player to earn 50 Victory Points is the winner.

Name: Pokamates
Description:
Grab your friends to begin this addictive, fun generating, family game, combining a splash of poker, topped with a taste of Scrabble. An exciting new poker board game for the whole family, played by 2 to 4 people.

Players take turns, arranging poker hands, either horizontally or vertically on the board.

Features a funky felt playing board
Four Double Score and four Triple Score indicators
PokaMates playing cards, 80 PokaMates chips, Score sheet and Instruction sheet

Name: Renaissance Inventors at War
Description:
A card and board skirmish game for 2 players themed on renaissance warfare with Leonardo da Vinci style inventions. The setting is Italian City States at war circa 1490 - the Fivizzano are invading the Piombino.

Play is conducted on a 16 x 16 square grid map. Each 8 x 8 section is referred to as a quadrant – the 2 eastern quadrants are land, the 2 western quadrants are water. The 6 squares of the NE corner of the SW quadrant contain city squares -  the Port City commune of Piombino. The remainder of the map layout is determined at discretion of the players though most of the land spaces should be flat land with a few clumps of forests and mountains and a few solitary hills, villages, and swamps. 
One road connects the city to a village or two and then goes off the map. A few Islands dot the Tyrrhenian Sea.  Terrain types will affect the movement of the different unit types.

There are 11 different unit types: Infantry, Engineers, Cavalry, Artillery, War Machine, Flying Machine, Fortification, Small Warship, Large Warship, Transport and Mine Field.  Each unit type has a move rating, hits score and range, and may have a special capability.

The players start with a pre-defined army comprising a mix of the various units.  The attacker (the Fivizzano) starts with his units in the bottom half of the Southern quadrants. In addition the Fivizzano gets one roll against the leader table and 4 rolls against the invention table – these give advantages / enhancements that last for the duration of the battle. The defender (the Piombino) starts with units scattered in the Northern quadrants, one roll against the leader table and 6 against the invention table.

Players share a Tactics deck comprising cards that mostly give short duration benefits.  These cards can be used, when appropriate, to enhance your own actions or negate those of your opponent

Players take turns with each turn comprising 4 Phases:

Draw Phase

     Draw 2 Tactics cards. 


Move Phase

     Each of your Units may be moved once up to a number of spaces equal to its move rating. 


Attack Phase

      Each of your units may make 1 attack vs. a target within its range. When attacking roll 1D10. On a roll of 7 or higher the attack is successful and the target loses 1 hit. A unit with zero hits is destroyed. 


End Phase 

     Max Hand size is 5 cards. Discard excess cards. 


The Fivizzano win if they occupy 4 of the spaces of the city. 
The Piombinos win if they destroy 20 or more units.

Name: Rento
Description:
Rento is advanced business dice game. 
In the game you roll "Wheel Of Fortune", trade lands, build houses, win auctions, roll 2 metal dices and one special dice and most importantly - have fun.
The goal of Rento game is to bankrupt the other players by taking rents and becoming the richest player.

You have to predict chances, calculate risk and make smart trades. However that is not so easy because the game has strategic game tweaks that are dynamically changing the game, so you have to be careful.

Good luck!

Name: Spore Stages
Description:
A card and dice game for 1-5 players based on the Spore series of videogames. Each player is control of his own race as it evolves and develops from a single cell to spacefaring.

The game plays in 5 stages (Cell stage, Creature stage, Tribal stage, Civilization stage, Space stage) with each stage having a separate deck of trait cards, and event, challenge type and challenge result tables.  Players move from one stage to the next at different speeds and do not directly interact until the last stage, the Space stage. At the beginning of each stage, each player chooses 1 characteristic for his race – these characteristics improve a particular attribute for the race.

Players share a common set of Victory Point Tokens (VT), Food (Resource) Tokens (FT), Hunger Tokens (HT) and Death Tokens (DT). Each player starts with 1 VT and 3 FT.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 5 Phases:

Mutation Phase

     Draw 1 (or, possibly, more) card from the deck (of the stage you are in). 


Event Phase

     Roll once on the event table (of the stage you are in) and resolve the event. 


Selection Phase

     Most events are challenges between your species and another species that is either weaker, equal, or stronger than you. 
     To resolve a challenge first roll on the challenge type table to determine what attribute will affect the challenge.  Next Roll 1D6 (Attribution Roll) and add your level in the indicated Attribute. This is your Attribution Total. 
     Next roll 1D6, 2D6, or 3D6 depending on the Strength of the Challenger. 


This is the Challenge Roll. 

     If the Attribution Total is greater than the Challenge Roll, you win the Challenge. 


If it is equal or less, you lose the challenge. 

     Refer to that stage’s Challenge Result list to determine the benefits or consequences of winning or losing the challenge.
     You may attempt to evade a challenge. If you do so, add +4 to your attribution roll. 


However if you win, you get no reward.

Evolution Phase

     You may gain 1 Trait by playing 1 Trait card from your hand and paying its cost in food or resource tokens. The Trait card stays in play in front of you.  


Metabolic Phase

     Discard 1 Food Token. If you have no food tokens gain 1 hunger token. If you have 2 hunger tokens, discard them and gain 1 death token. 
     Max hand size is 5 cards. Discard excess cards. 
     Determine whether your race moves to the next stage:
         If you have 6 Trait cards in Cell stage in play go on Creature stage. 
         If you have 8 Trait cards in Creature stage in play go on Tribal stage. 
         If you have won against 5 villages in Tribal stage go onto Civilization stage. 
         If you have won against 7 nations in Civilization stage go onto Space Stage. 
    
     If going on to the next stage set your old Trait cards aside in your Progress Pile. Except for and VT they might score, these do not apply to later stages. Select a new characteristic for the new stage and discard down to 2 FT or RT. 


The game ends after any player has completed his 15th turn in the Space stage at which point scoring is undertaken:

         Gain 5 VT for completing the Civilization stage and entering the Space stage. 
         Add up the VT bonuses from all the Trait cards in your Progress Pile. 
         Each Death Token counts as a -2 VT penalty. 
         Add or lose VT arising from Events and Challenges. 
    


The player with the most Victory Point Tokens wins.
